course_title: Working with Students with Challenging Behaviours

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the relationship between student quality of life and challenging behaviour.
Demonstrate an understanding of the environments, conditions and/or characteristics that make individuals vulnerable to the development of challenging behaviour;
Identify evidence-based strategies that prevent or reduce challenging behaviours across a range of environments;
Demonstrate an understanding of the importance of assessment and data to understanding the functions of challenging behaviour for a particular individual;
Critically evaluate research that reports on interventions for challenging behaviour;
Demonstrate written communication skills consistent with appropriate conventions of the American Psychological Association Publication Manual

assessments.task_description:
Behaviours of concern/challenging behaviours by school-aged students with impairments can be a significant barrier to their academic and social inclusion. With a human right to education and strategies that have an empirical basis, it is critical that such students are provided with interventions and strategies that are effective in decreasing the use of challenging behaviours and improving their quality of life.

You will need to:

  1. Read this helpful blog on Concept Mapping: https://www.uow.edu.au/student/learning-co-op/effective-studying/concept-mapping/ - :~:text=To make a concept map,read and not overly complex.
  2. Make a choice of how you want to complete your Concept Map. You can either:
  3. Draw your Concept Map using pen and paper. When complete, you will take a photo; or
  4. Write your concepts on post-it notes and move these around on a table or board. Again, when complete, take a photo; or
  5. Complete an electronic concept map. In class, we will show you one program called MindMup https://www.mindmup.com/ It is free to use. If you choose to use it, here are some tutorials to get you started: https://www.mindmup.com/tutorials/index.html
  6. Conduct a broad literature search and review peer-reviewed research literature in relation to the meaning of “student quality of life”, for school-aged students. When you investigate this, you need to look at student quality of life broadly (beyond school) as well as their educational quality of life (at school).
  7. Conduct a second, more narrow literature search and review peer-reviewed research literature in relation to the specific challenges faced at school by one of the following group of students. You can, if desired, narrow this search to a particular age or year level, such as early childhood, primary or high school. You are then required to show how student quality of life can be strengthened (think about changes to systems, environments, practices). Your choice of student groups you can focus on include:
  8. Student with intellectual or cognitive disabilities
  9. Autistic students
  10. Students with a sensory disability impacting vision or hearing
  11. Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander (Indigenous) students
  12. Students from culturally or linguistically diverse backgrounds
  13. Gifted and talented students
  14. Other students, by negotiation with the Course Co-ordinator
  15. You may present a broad concept map that explores quality of life across multiple domains, or a deeper concept map that examines quality of life across one targeted domain. Your decision will be guided by the literature you identify through your search. If you exceed the 1,000-word limit, you may need to narrow your focus.
  16. Present your findings as a concept map (see example below) showing how student quality of life can be strengthened your selected group of students by addressing the challenges they experience at school. We will discuss concept mapping at the Week 1 Lecture. The total word limit for your concept map should be 1000 words, with a margin of 1,100 words maximum.
  17. Copy and paste either your photo or an image of your electronic concept map into a Word Document.
  18. Below the image, provide a reference list using APA referencing style. The reference list will not contribute to your word limit.
  19. Read the criteria sheet to ensure you have addressed all criteria.
  20. Upload your completed word document to Blackboard for grading before the due date.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2: Plan for School wide PBS
assessments.task_description:
“The goal of effective classroom management is not creating “perfect” children, but providing the perfect environment for enhancing their growth, using research-based strategies that guide students toward increasingly responsible and motivated behavior” (Sprick et al., 2006).

Effective strategies for working with students with challenging behaviours start with preventing those behaviours in the first place. This assessment is focused on Tier 1 implementation of school-wide positive behaviour supports that are universal, across all students, in all environments, are preventative and proactive (Sugai & Horner, 2002). Setting up students and classrooms for academic and social success is a critical foundation for positive behaviour supports. Therefore, it is essential that teachers plan for positive, proactive, and instructional approaches to classroom management.

Taking the role of the classroom teacher, you will develop a narrated PowerPoint presentation that discusses Tier 1 school-wide positive behaviour supports for the classroom. This presentation should demonstrate an understanding of the essential elements school-wide positive behaviour supports and include the essential skills for classroom management as well as Tier 1 classroom practices.

Within your presentation, please ensure that you cite the academic literature as this is an important aspect of this assessment task.

You will need to:

  1. Complete a review of literature to learn more about Positive Behaviour Support and Tier 1 classroom practices, as well as the Essential Skills for Classroom Management.
  2. Then, use your notes from the steps above to design a PowerPoint presentation and write a transcript for this presentation (2,000 words).
  3. Make a PowerPoint presentation outlining how you would implement Tier 1 school-wide positive behaviour supports in a classroom setting. This presentation must include:
  4. Slide 1: A description of the class setting (year level etc.) and what might make this setting challenging for students.
  5. Slide 2: The strategies you will use to develop behavioural expectations, as how you would create a shared understanding of those behavioural expectations. Include at least one example of a positive behavioural expectation (what the expected behaviour looks like in measurable and observable terms).
  6. Slide 3: Tier 1 classroom practices you would use in your classroom.
  7. Slide 4: How you would use the Essential Skills for Classroom Management in your classroom.
  8. Slide 5: The strategies you will use to support the demonstration of the behavioural expectation(s) you have identified, by all members of the classroom.
  9. Slide 6: The strategies you will use to discourage behaviours that are inconsistent with the behavioural expectation(s) you have identified.
  10. Slide 7: How you would know whether these Tier 1 practices are being implemented with fidelity.
  11. Reflect on ways that you will make it clear that your PowerPoint Presentation has been informed by scholarly literature (You may, for example, want to ensure you have both in text references as well as a reference list at the end of your presentation).
  12. Check the criteria sheet again to ensure you have met all criteria.
  13. Finally, record your narrated PowerPoint presentation. Your video can be edited if necessary. We will discuss this further in class.

Upload your narrated PowerPoint presentation recording as well as your transcript to Blackboard for marking.

assessments.task_description:
School-wide positive behaviour support takes a whole of school approach that focuses on improving a school's ability to teach expectations and support positive behaviour for all students. It is important that teachers and other professionals have skills across a multi-tiered system of positive behaviour supports. This includes having a good understanding of approaches and processes in the assessment and planning of positive behaviour supports for individual students. This assessment requires the student to put into practice the knowledge and skills acquired through this course.

During the semester students identify a person (actual or from a case study) who engages in challenging behaviours. In weekly activities, students will identify a challenging behaviour they will address through the development of a positive behaviour support plan. For the background of this assessment students will formulate a mock functional behavioural assessment, and, based on the mock assessment, develop a positive behaviour support plan.

The requirements of this written assessment are;

  1. A completed mock Functional Behavioural Assessment including Summary Statements
  2. A completed Positive Behaviour Support Plan informed by mock functional behavioural assessment using the template provided and includes;
  3. A brief overview of the focus person for whom this positive behaviour plan has been developed;
  4. An operational definition of the target behaviour;
  5. Behaviour and other support strategies;
  6. An overview of the strategies that will be used to support the implementation of the plan within the School (or other) setting.

NOTE 1: This is intended to be a practical assessment where you demonstrate your understanding of the specific skills and knowledge in positive behaviour support and apply them in practice. There is no requirement in the marking criteria that references are used.

NOTE 2: Students are required to use the plan template provided.

NOTE 3: More detailed requirements and marking criteria for this assessment is provided on the UQ Learn site for EDUC7230
